abstract.p: Runner Roger Bannister, inducted into International Scholar-Athlete Hall of Fame, calls for increased use of blood testing to curb use of performance-enhancing drugs by track and field athletes, interview (M)

block.p: Roger Bannister, the first person to run a sub-four-minute mile, said today he thought that increased use of blood testing could help curb the use of performance-enhancing drugs by track and field athletes.

Urine testing is fine for anabolic steroids but less sensitive than blood testing, Bannister said in an inteview before he was inducted into the International Scholar-Athlete Hall of Fame on the campus of the University of Rhode Island in Kingston.

It's best if you set a criteria for an average amount of red cells and if someone goes beyond that level they can't compete. But there's quite a bit of opposition to blood-testing because a lot of people feel it's an offense against a person.

Bannister, 71, who has written and lectured extensively on neurology while also serving on several British and international sports bodies, was inducted 46 years to the day that he broke the 4-minute barrier for the mile. On April 6, 1954, Bannister, a 25-year-old medical student, ran a mile in 3 minutes 59.4 seconds on a cinder track at Oxford University, which he had attended.

Also inducted into the hall of fame today were Tenley Albright, also a medical doctor who in 1953 became the first American woman to win a world figure skating championship and who won a gold medal in figure skating in the 1956 Winter Olympics; Joan Benoit Samuelson, who in 1983 set a world record in the women's marathon and then won the first women's Olympic marathon in 1984, and Paul Robeson, an all-America football player at Rutgers who went on to become an internationally acclaimed singer, actor and political activist.
